item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The Shaman

I went to the neighborhood spiritual second-hand bookstore and bought a psuedo-scientific book about the benefits of meditation; it's called The Relaxation Response by Herbert Benson.  My friend F recommended it.  Now it's on the shelf along with some other books I intend to read.  It was only $3.00.

The bookstore owner there is from Nigeria.  His name is Abraham.  He's an interesting fellow who really knows a lot about spiritual affairs.  After I bought the book, we talked for a few minutes.  He told me that all religions "failed" in some way.  He declared that one didn't need "salvation" from anything, like from "sin" as in Christianity, or like from "suffering" as in Buddhism.  I asked him if he believed in an Immortal Soul, something that Buddhism does not acknowledge because Buddhists believe we are a never-ending "stream of consciousness," not really a soul.  He said he believed in an Immortal Soul.  Then he said that there is only One Truth and that it cannot be verbalized; it must be experienced.  That's an interesting perspective indeed.  It got me thinking on my way home...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: When you think about living and your life expressed here, the greatest expression it to live by the golden rule. Although a very simple concept, it is quite difficult to live up to when so many others do not. As for the other dimensions, yes, stream of consciousness is one of them. We are all here to expreience every element of our journey back to what we call God. BTW, our "highest" mental achievement (brilliance, IQ, mental) is nothing compared to many dimensions of existence. When in prayer or meditation, you are already connected to a higher level than our highest mental self.

"...there is only One Truth and that it cannot be verbalized; it must be experienced."

What a unique point of view; I like this quite a bit. Thanks, viktoro!

If only there were a local club for Lojban...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Sunny autumn day
At the Cafe
A neighbor
Arguing about bias in the media
One face heated and over-excited
One face calm and serene
Hot and cold
Delusions and illusions
Looking for wisdom in irritating people
There must be other ways

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I have been both calm and serene and heated and over-excited. Both can be justified by each, but observers prefer calm and serene!

I gine the heated and over-exited types exibit a passion for the subject (and, in most times, their own lives!) and that the "calm and serence" person has hit a "hot" subject.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
All the Leaves Are Brown

I don't know about you, but one thing I find particularly useless that I see people doing all the time is sweeping or raking the leaves off the lawn and sidewalks during the fall.  Why don't they just let them decompose naturally?  Hmmm.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
For this one I do have an answer!  Maple leaves are super....they decompose with no problem. Oak leaves on the other hand kill anything they cover...I know this because I have maple trees from which I rarely rake the leaves....my neighbor has oak trees and is known to "share" his leaves with MY yard when I am away!     I lost an entire section of grass one year from his leaves!

I have a motto that my neighbors don't share....goes for snow and leaves..."If God put it there then God will take it away...."
Don't forget these are the same people who buy fertilizer! I love leaves...eventually they dry up and blow away...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Atole

Atole is a Mexican hot beverage made with ground corn, or masa. It is prepared with milk or water, sweetened with refined sugar or piloncillo (semi-processed brown sugar sold in cones) and flavored with cinnamon, fruit, almonds or chocolate. It is served with breakfast, dinner or as a snack, and is always served with the traditional King's Cake (Rosca de Reyes). Atole has the consistency of heavy cream.

Ingredients

  • 3 cups water
  • ½ pound fest corn masa dough or masa prepared from masa harina (1 cup)
  • 5 cups milk
  • 2 Tbsp. cornstarch
  • 2 orange leaves (optional)
  • 3 cinnamon sticks, each 4 inches long
  • 1 ½ cups sugar, or to taste

Directions

  • Dissolve the masa dough in 1 cup water.
  • Strain the mixture through cheesecloth and transfer to a medium saucepan. Cook about 15 minutes.
  • Add remaining water, milk, cornstarch, orange leaves and cinnamon and cook, stirring regularly with a wooden spoon, till thick, about 30 minutes.
  • When the mixture has thickened, remove from heat and add sugar.
  • Return to heat to melt sugar and cook until the atole is the consistency of heavy cream.
  • If too thick, add milk to achieve preferred consistency.
  • Remove orange leaves and cinnamon stick and serve hot in clay mugs.
  • If desired, add fresh fruit just before serving.


Recipe courtesy of Gayle Watkins

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think this is why in my next lifetime I am coming back Hispanic! I will try to make it, but better yet, find a Mexican restaurant to make it for me! Gracias! (And thank you for your comment on my site...I am trying to be upbeat for the sake of Cheryl's mother who has suffered long and mightily, a long share more than mine. At this point I am just waiting for the call informing me of her passing.)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Synchronicity

Do you remember that catchy song from The Police (Sting)?

Have you ever thought of something then you hear it or see something about it the next moment?  It's something like an unusual coincidence...  That's "synchronicity."   Some say it's totally random, some say there's a "meaning" behind it.  It depends if the person has a semantic or non-semantic view of the universe...
 

The following was quoted from http://www.largocanyon.org/pi/synchronicity/synch2.htm

----

{BEGIN QUOTE}

Notes from Aziz

Aziz, R. (1990). C. G. Jung's psychology of religion and synchronicity. New York: State University of New York.

Why Does Synchronicity Happen: various sources

  • Synchronicity reveals the meaningful connections between the subjective and objective world. Jung
  • Synchronistic events provide an immediate religious experience as a direct encounter with the compensatory patterning of events in nature as a whole, both inwardly and outwardly. Jung.
  • These events serve to nurture -support, protect and enhance- human life and spiritual growth. Peck. 1978. The Road Less Traveled.
  • It is unfathomable power [the fingers of the Morai (fate), or the providence of God] ordering the web of our inner and outer existence. Greene. 1984. The Astrology of Fate.
  • The First Insight Theory: Mysterious coincidences cause the reconsideration of the inherent mystery that surrounds our individual lives on this planet. Redfield. 1993. The Celestine Prophecy
  • They demonstrate the unity of psyche and matter, forcing us to transcend our rational, scientific, materialistic attitudes. Mansfield, 1995. Synchronicity, Science, and Soul-making.

[with annotations by JRW]

Jung's Model (Aziz, p. 61-62)

All synchronistic phenomena can be grouped under three categories:

1 The coincidence of a psychic state in the observer with a simultaneous objective, external event that corresponds to the psychic state or content, (e.g. the scarab), where there is no evidence of a causal connection between the psychic state and the external event, and where, considering the psychic relativity of space and time, such a connection is not even conceivable.

2. The coincidence of a psychic state with a corresponding (more or less simultaneous) external even taking place outside the observer's field of perception, i.e. at a distance, and only verifiable afterward (e.g. the Stockholm fire).

3. The coincidence of a psychic state with a corresponding, not yet existent future event that is distant in time and can likewise only be verified afterward.

Two Fundamental Types of Synchronicity (Aziz, p. 59)

1. One in which the compensatory activity of the archetype is experienced both inwardly and outwardly. [the event seems to emerge from the subconscious with access to absolute knowledge, which cannot be consciously known]

2. One in which the compensatory activity of the archetype is experienced outwardly only. [ these convey to the ego a much-needed wholeness of the self's perspective, they show one a new perspective]

Essential Characteristics of the Synchronistic Event

1) The specific intrapsychic state of the subject defined as one of the following:

a) The unconscious content which, in accordance with the compensatory needs of the conscious orientation, enters consciousness [something is in our conscious]

b) The conscious orientation of the subject around which the compensatory synchronistic activity centers [something happens concerning what is in our mind]

2) An objective event corresponds with this intrapsychic state [may be literal or figurative correspondence]

a) The objective event as a compensatory equivalent to the unconscious compensatory content

b) The objective event as the sole compensatory of the ego-consciousness

3) Even though the intrapsychic state and the objective event may be synchronous according to clock time and spatially near to each other, the objective event may, contrary to this, be distant in time and/or space in relation to the intrapsychic state [as in telepathy, clairvoyance, etc.]

4) The intrapsychic state and the objective event are not causally related to each other [acausality]

5) The synchronistic event is meaningful [excludes some coincidence, but does not require the meaning to be understood]

a) The intrapsychic state and the objective event as meaningful parallels

b) The numinous charge associated with the synchronistic experience [feeling of spiritual experience]

c) Import of the subjective-level interpretation [the content must reflect back on the issues of the individual]

d) the archetypal level of meaning [transcends the individual and implies absolute knowledge].

{END QUOTE}

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Interesting.
This is my whole life...this is very well done.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The following article is quoted from http://neptune.spaceports.com/~words/lojban.html ; I thought it interesting so I posted it here...

------

Welcome to Lojbanistan!

Lojban, in Lojban, means "logical language" (the j is pronounced as in French bonjour)  Lojbanistan is both an imaginary country where Lojban is spoken and, in practice, the international community of Lojban-speakers.

Lojban itself came out of an earlier language project called Loglan, and it shares Loglan's interest in the "Sapir-Whorf hypothesis" -  the idea that the language you speak affects the way you think.  Most people who have learnt a foreign language, or have grown up speaking two languages, will be familiar with this idea, having found themselves thinking and speaking in one language or the other because something is easier to say in that language.  One of the main ideas behind the Loglan/Lojban project was to create a language which is both highly expressive and as culturally neutral as possible, then see what people from different cultures do with it.  To give an example, in most European languages time and gender are very important - you can say "She goes," "It went,"  "He'll go" and so on, but just to say "She/he/it go," with no particular gender or time in mind, sounds strange.  In Chinese, on the other hand, ta qu (he/she/it go) is perfectly normal.  In Lojban there are plenty of words to show the time of an action, its length, how it happens and so on - but you don't have to use any of them.  If I really wanted to, I could say:

  •  le ninmu puzuze'udi'i klama
  •  the female-human past-long-time-distance-long-time-interval-regularly go
  •  A long time ago, for a long time, she went regularly.
But normally I'd just say:
  • klama
  • [someone / something] go
Notice that you can translate the first example into English (more-or-less) but the second one just won't go into English, or most European languages.  If you're European and this strikes you as odd, you may have just witnessed a Sapir-Whorf effect!

However, if Lojban only existed as some kind of experiment to test the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis, probably very few people would bother to learn it.  In fact, Lojban's other uses have taken over so much that quite a few Lojbanists who don't believe much in Sapir-Whorf still use the language because of its other benefits.  Some that I've heard are:

  • It encourages you to think clearly and logically.
  • It lets you express ideas precisely, but allows you to be vague when you want to.
  • It can easily express a much wider range of emotions than most natural languages.
  • It helps you step out of your cultural conditioning.
  • Computers can understand it.
  • It's good for discussing philosophy.
  • It's good for writing poetry ...
... and so on.  Not all Lojbanists would agree with all of these statements - we are not language missionaries - but there's something in the language for almost everyone.

In the long-term, Lojban has more ambitious goals.  Some ways that people have suggested Lojban can be used are:

  • As a language for human-computer interaction and artificial intelligence research.
  • As an interlanguage for translation - it would probably be easier and more accurate to translate from, say, Korean into Lojban then from Lojban to German, than directly from Korean to German.
  • As a "meta-language" i.e. a language for describing languages.
  • As a language for international law.
  • As a way of improving our understanding of different cultures.
  • As a tool in psychotherapy and other forms of self-development.
  • As an international language.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
:)            ^_^

Lojban, the logical language, has a wide range of emoticons that are said out loud:

.a'o  

hope

.au  

desire

.a'u  

interest

.ie  

agreement

.i'e  

approval

.ii  

fear (think of "Eeek!")

.iu  

love

.oi  

complaint

.ua  

discovery, "Ah, I get it!"

.ue  

surprise

.u'e  

wonder, "Wow!"

.ui  

happiness

.u'i  

amusement

.u'u  

repentance, "I'm sorry!"

.uu  

pity, sympathy

The apostrophe is pronounced like an H.  "uu" is like "woo" and "ii" is like "yee."

I'm just wondering where in Canada you live?

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Logical Lojban

A response to bjorn.  I made a blog of it because it is interesting...

Having looked at Lojban grammar, I notice that tense is even optional in any sentence.  It looks like there is room for ambiguity there, which is a human thing as you say.  I know Chinese has no tense, but it has aspect.  Lojban makes tense and aspect optional.  As you are a language teacher, I think you know what I am talking about...  But the good thing about Lojban is that precision is easily possible if it is desired.  I'm studying Lojban a little because it is attractive in a postmodern way.

By the way, one of the motivations for creating Lojban was to test the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis, which states that to a weak or strong degree, depending on the linguist, one's thoughts are moulded by the language one uses.  In other words, one's perspective of the universe is affected by the language one uses.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: What's up, a bit late on the reply, but thanks for the comment on my site. I had to at least show my respects for what happened on 9/11. Nice site you got here.

I can see how aspect could be optional without losing much of the meaning, but if tense is optional, wouldn't that make statements less accurate? In a narrative for example, if you are describing a number of chronologically interrelated events, how do you make yourself clear without tense markers? I can imagine that a narrative can have a real sense of immediacy though, if tense is not used (like using the present simple in English).

About the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis, what view of the universe would one acquire if one used Lojban regularly? A strictly scientific view? Sounds interesting, though. I think that it works the other way more: your culture and worldview will mold the language you use. We Swedes don't have a wide selection of 'small talk' phrases (like the British do) becuase we value privacy and we don't assume others want to talk to us. I don't think it's because we don't have these phrases in our language that we've become reserved and prefer to get down to business without much ado.

But having said that, I have this feeling I'm taking on another persona when I speak English. And I've changed a great deal since I started using English as my language of habitual use in the early 80's. But to say that English has moulded me? I'm not sure...

To Bjorn:

The optional tense in Lojban is a really strange concept indeed.  I suppose that when chronology is important in what one is discussing, then one is obliged to use the tense particles.  But if one wants to sound "mathematical," one can leave out tenses.  "Optional" here means "only use when needed."  Maybe "discretionary" is a better word.  Remember, that as a Swede, you might find the whole idea strange, but the Chinese make do without grammatical tense all the time.

It is probably a scientific, "logical," culturally neutral view that one would would acquire if one used Lojban regularly.  It is strict philosophy.

The Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis is controversial in the linguistics field.  There are believers in "weak linguistic determinism" and "strong linguistic determinism."  Maybe you are of the former.  Right now, I tend to the latter...  It's just from my observations of different cultures and peoples.

From a Chapter on Tenses in the Beginner's Lojban Lessons...

"By this time, you may be wondering what has happened to all the tenses. After all, a large part of learning a language is learning tenses, and figuring out which one you ought to be using. English, for example, has about a dozen tenses (depending on what you count as a tense) and some languages have more. Use the wrong one and you're, well, wrong. In addition, there are a load of words and phrases like before, in a while, some time ago and so on.

"Lojban deals with time quite differently. Like some other languages (e.g. Chinese), tense is not compulsory. All the bridi we've looked at so far have had no particular time attached to them, and this is perfectly acceptable; in fact it is normal. Saying mi klama ti de'i la padjed. is good Lojban, even if out of context we don't know if it means I'm coming here next Monday, or I came here last Monday. In most cases, sentences don't happen out of context, and the context is usually enough to tell us if we're talking about the past, present or future. Putting a past tense in just because the same sentence in English would be in the past tense can be rather malglico."

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Jorge Llambías wrote the following poem in Lojban. (It appeared on the Lojban mailing list a while ago.)
.oisai le nicte
le selgei ca'o kunti
.ije do darno

The translation:

Oh, the night
is still void of joy
And you are far away

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I've always been wary of translations of books in any language, it amazes me how two books, supposedly from the same author, can read so differently by two different translators. The interpretation of poetry is made all the worse, though with the short three lines, hopefully it can't go too far wrong!

====================================

I have read small parts of Lao Tzu's philosophy and have enjoyed what I have read. I'd probably replace minimalism with the word 'moderation' otherwise there's the danger of bordering ascetism.
As for the soft and weak overpowering the hard and strong - you only have to look at Ghandi! If only the Palestinians understood this!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Lojban: The Logical Language

Official Webpage:
http://www.lojban.org/

Yahoo Discussion List:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/lojban/

"Lojban is a carefully constructed spoken language designed in the hope of removing a large portion of the ambiguity from human communication. It was made well-known by a Scientific American article, and references in both science fiction and computer publications. Lojban has been built over five decades by dozens of workers, and hundreds of supporters."

Its grammar is based on predicate logic, a kind of math.  The vocabulary is taken from the six most spoken languages in the world.  So it is quite culturally neutral as far as grammar and vocabulary go.

Personally, among artificial languages, I much prefer Esperanto ( http://www.esperanto.net/ ), a kind of streamlined Romance language, which is easier to learn and has a more human face.  But being a techno kind of guy, I am curious about Lojban right now.  It's almost like some kind of robo-talk...

The following excerpt was taken from a Lojban translation of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland:

la alis co'a tatpi le nu zutse le rirxe korbi re'o le mensi gi'e zukte fi noda i abuboi paji'ireroi sutra zgana le cukta poi le mensi cu tcidu i ku'i cy vasru no pixra ja nuncasnu i lu ji'a ma prali sei la alis pensi fi lo cukta poi vasru no pixra ja nuncasnu li'u

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I looked at the Lojban site. Interesting, but I'm deeply suspicious of a language that tries to eliminate ambiguity. Isn't ambiguity precisely what makes human communication what it is? Life has a million shades of grey, and I think any language, even if it is completely void of ambiguity at the outset, will inevitibly become ambiguous. And, as all languages change with time, no grammar will remain free of exceptions for very long either, I don't think. But maybe it would be useful in international business negotiations? Safeguarding against any misunderstanding?

Having looked at Lojban grammar, I notice that tense is even optional in any sentence.  It looks like there is room for ambiguity there, which is a human thing as you say.  I know Chinese has no tense, but it has aspect.  Lojban makes tense and aspect optional.  As you are a language teacher, I think you know what I am talking about...  But the good thing about Lojban is that precision is easily possible if it is desired.  I'm studying Lojban a little because it is attractive in a postmodern way.

By the way, one of the motivations for creating Lojban was to test the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis, which states that to a weak or strong degree, depending on the linguist, one's thoughts are moulded by the language one uses.  In other words, one's perspective of the universe is affected by the language one uses.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Eternal Peace

My grandma passed away yesterday.  She was 89.  My grandpa, her husband, died last December.  He was 92.  May they both rest in peace.

Myself, I am skeptical that there is a heaven or hell.  Even about reincarnation, I have some doubts, but we do see cycles everywhere in nature so it seems plausible that life energy could be recycled.  My current theory is quite simple:  When we die, we simply do not exist anymore and a deep, eternal peace is the result of non-existence, something like the deep sleep in the middle of the night when we do not know we exist.

A strange coincidence or synchronicity happened yesterday on the day my grandma died.  In a department store downtown, I accidentally met an Indian couple, Chris and Heydar from Britain, who was touring here in Canada.  I met them before in Greece last May; they were part of my tour group there.  They were so friendly.  When I saw them in that department store here, I had just gone to the Central Library and borrowed a book out on Pali, which is the Buddhist scriptural language, an extinct language from India.  I showed Chris the book.  It was strange and coincidental.  It was highly improbable that I met that couple again:  once in Greece, now in Canada... Highly improbable!  We were all very surprised that we had by chance met each other again.  Later I imagined that it was a Sign.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm sorry to hear about your grandmother. =(

Hi there... I know what you mean about coincidences. I felt them all the time. I can really understand your loss. Both my parents died last year (2001) prematurely so I've been grieving myself. I think it's cool that you met the same people again...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Geofiction Club!

geofiction-subscribe@yahoogroups.com

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It seems interesting; what does the club do, though?
Members of the club discuss and present ideas about geofiction.  If a member has created an imaginary place or culture or language and wish to publicize it, then the club is the place to do it.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Good News from Tibet!

AFP Report 24th May 2-02

* Chinese in Tibet must study language *

BEIJING - China has passed a new law to require people from its Han majority living in Tibet to study the Tibetan language and protect it from 'globalisation'.

The provision was included in a law passed on Wednesday by Tibet's Parliament and was aimed at protecting the ancient language from 'globalisation', according to the official China Daily.

Many overseas groups claim that the biggest threat to Tibet's unique traditional culture comes from deliberate Chinese attempts to eradicate the region's legacy.

The newspaper did not say whether the law provides specific standards for the level of proficiency that Han Chinese and other non-Tibetans will have to attain.

The report said that the Tibetan language began to evolve only 1,300 years ago. While a written language for Tibetan was developed in the seventh century AD, the language itself is believed to be much older.

It is now spoken by an estimated five million people, not only in Tibet proper, but also in the Chinese provinces of Qinghai and Gansu and in parts of the Indian subcontinent. --AFP

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Something ELSE I did not know! Thanks for the info...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Interesting Essay of the Moment...

Pioneers or Pariahs? Young Adults Who Choose to Live Simply
By John O. Andersen

        Is simple living just for the well-heeled who've already "made it"? What about young adults without pensions or mortgage-free property? Can they live simply?

        A frequent criticism of voluntary simplicity is many of its vocal members are aging baby boomers who took it up only after having high-paying careers, and accumulating at least partial pensions. Critics argue such people's decision to downshift is eased by the fact that they had enough assets to make it feasible. The implication is that the choice of voluntary simplicity by younger, less financially secure adults, presents considerably greater challenges.

        By voluntary simplicity, I refer to the decision to reduce clutter (possessions, time commitments, etc.) and consume less. It's not about denying oneself the pleasures of life, but rather replacing mediocre pleasures with better ones. It's about living more deliberately.

        More than a few of the books, newsletters, and articles in the past decade on the subject of simple living were written by former professionals in their late 40s and 50s. The unspoken message from these people's lives is the nose-to-the-grindstone-years are generally a prerequisite before moving on to simplicity. Little if anything is said about whether young people could successfully short-circuit the "mandatory" slog and jump right into a simple lifestyle.

See full essay at:

http://www.unconventionalideas.com/pariah.html

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Brainwaves

I was reading a book about meditation and I learned a few things about brainwaves.

When you are most relaxed, or before and just after you sleep, you have alpha waves at 8-13 cycles per second.  Most of your active waking hours are in beta waves at 13-30 cycles per second.  When you are asleep, you have theta and delta waves.

Alpha waves can be induced by meditation.

In alpha, your senses are most receptive and time seems to slow down.  The sky seems bluer; your skin feels the slight breeze more intensely.

I seem to be in alpha a lot I guess.  That's why I feel I have enough time during the day.  Most people I know dwell in beta too much.

Beta waves
(very low amplitude, high frequency; 13 to 30 waves/sec)		 A person is awaken and active (in a state of alertness ). They are the fastest [EEG] waves and signal an active cortex and an intense state of attention. Irregular register (unsynchronized).
Alpha waves
(low amplitude, 8 to 13 waves/sec)		 A person is awaken and relaxed, with closed eyes. Neurons are firing at different times. Regular register (synchronized).
Theta waves (low-medium amplitude, spike-like waves; 3-7 waves/sec) A person is sleepy, already sleeping, or in a sleep transition. It can be observed in from the hippocampus. Theta rhythm is also observed in REM sleep. Because the hippocampus is involved in memory processing, the presence of theta rhythm during REM sleep in that region of the brain might be related to that [memory] activity.
Delta waves
(high amplitude, low frequency; 3 waves/sec) 		A person is deep asleep*. Neurons, which are not engaged in the processing of information, are firing all at the same time. Therefore, the activity is synchronized. Waves are large and slow.
REM
60 to 70
waves/sec		 Maximal retraction of the pupil and nictating membrane follow the volleys of ocular movements

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Mars-like Lab Conditions Support Life
By SPACE.com Staff
posted: 01:25 pm ET
19 August 2002

A laboratory experiment simulating conditions on Mars found that certain terrestrial microorganisms called methanogens can survive in extreme Mars-like conditions involving low air pressure.

While the work does not by any means suggest there is or ever was life on Mars, it illustrates one possible way primitive organisms might have once thrived on the Red Planet or could even exist below the surface today, according to Tim Kral of the University of Arkansas.


   More Stories

Bioastronomy 2002: Extending the Boundaries of Astrobiology

Bizarre Creature in Idaho Raises Prospects for Life on Mars

Water Ice Discovery on Mars May Be 'Tip of an Iceberg'

Odyssey Discovers Abundant Water Ice on Mars
Kral led the experiment and presented it to colleagues during a bioastronomy conference in Australia last month.

"Our goal is first to get the organisms to grow well, then systematically experiment with conditions found on Mars," Kral said last week.

His team first grew test tube cultures of various methanogens (organisms that thrive on methane rather than oxygen) in simulated Mars soil. Derived from altered volcanic ash, the soil approximates the composition, grain size, density, and magnetic properties of Martian soil. They then exposed the methanogens to various Martian conditions in a so-called Andromeda Chamber donated by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California.

Methanogen cultures were frozen, put into the chamber, and then the temperature was raised to Mars-like conditions and the pressure kept much lower than on Earth. Mars' thin atmosphere creates but a fraction of the air pressure of Earth.

So far, the tests indicate "low levels of methane production," Kral and his colleagues say, meaning the organisms are metabolizing.

There is no solid evidence for life on the Red Planet, but the new research builds on other recent discoveries that point to conditions being possible. Earlier this year, scientists announced strong evidence for vast amounts of water ice just below the surface of Mars. Water is thought to be a key ingredient for life.

Mars' atmosphere contains large amounts of carbon dioxide with almost no oxygen. Assuming that hydrogen and some water are present under the surface, the basic requirements for methanogen growth are met on Mars. And even if hydrogen is not present, carbon monoxide is, and some methanogens can use this instead of hydrogen.

A separate study released in January found methanogens living in complete darkness 660 feet (200 meters) underground here on Earth. They eat hydrogen, breathe carbon dioxide, and form the root of an ecosystem unlike any previously known on Earth.

Terraform?

Kral said if methanogens can grow well under simulated Martian conditions, it might be possible to take the organisms to Mars if humans ever colonize the planet.

"Of course, there are many potential ethical and environmental problems with this," Kral points out.

Since methane is a "greenhouse gas" that traps heat near a planet’s surface, methanogens could theoretically be used to raise Mars’ surface temperature, eventually "terraforming" the planet so that it could support life and provide a potential refuge for humanity.

Kral thinks this might take too long to be effective, though, perhaps hundreds or thousands of years.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Maybe on their own they'd be ineffective, but coupled with other forms of terraforming, it might make the difference between decades and centuries.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Pope Speaks Esperanto

Today (2002.08.16), in Poland, the birthplace of Esperanto, the Pope addressed a crowd in Esperanto. You can hear it at
http://start.at/retradio (find today's date). Below is an article concerning the Catholic Church's toying with the language.

--Viktoro

------------------------------------------------

USA Today Life Section 1/27/00

A religious belief in Esperanto
By Dru Sefton, Special for USA TODAY

A guide to Esperanto

What international language was founded in 1887?

That was a question on a recent Who Wants to Be a Millionaire. The contestant paused. Could it be Farsi? After polling the audience, he hesitatingly chose correctly:

Esperanto.

It's the language spoken around the world that remains relatively unknown. That soon might change. For the first time, a major institution, the Catholic Church in Germany, has agreed to consider using Esperanto to improve worldwide communication within the church, as traditional Latin fades away.

From May 31 to June 4 at the German Catholic Forum in Hamburg, dozens of speakers will lecture to 50,000 participants. One presentation, by Romanian Archbishop Gyorgy Jakubinyi, is titled "Esperanto: The New Latin of the Church?"


Esperanto? For those as puzzled as that quiz contestant, a primer:

It was developed by Ludovic Zamenhof, a young Polish doctor
frustrated by the confusion among speakers of Polish, Russian, German and Yiddish in his hometown of Bialystok. "Esperanto" means "one who hopes."

It uses words drawn from 700 roots common to European languages.

Its grammar is simple, with no irregular verbs.

It is phonetic, with words pronounced as spelled.

It is easy to master - enthusiasts say it takes an English speaker one-fifth as long to learn as Spanish or French.


Matthias Ulrich learned it 14 years ago as a college student in Germany. Last year he published a book on the language there. He will introduce the archbishop in Hamburg.

A guide to Esperanto

paroli - to speak
floro - flower
ami - to love
hundo - dog
tablo - table
fenestro - window
patrino - mother
traduki - to translate
esperi - to hope
eklezio - church
telefoni - to telephone
familio - family
arto - art
Interreto - Internet
genetika - genetic
tutmondigo - globalization
hommedia - environmental
merkato - market
vidbendo - videotape

Esperanto has been gaining popularity among young Europeans since the fall of the Soviet bloc in 1989, Ulrich says. This year there's a Catholic Esperanto Congress in Italy, plus a Christian Esperanto Congress and a Catholic Esperanto Youth Camp in the Czech Republic.

"The common language of Esperanto has enabled young people from all over Europe to have deep religious conversations and feel part of a worldwide community," Ulrich says from his home in Wiesbaden.

The Catholic Church has long supported Esperanto as a way for its diverse population to communicate, according to the International Catholic Esperanto Union (IKUE) . Its magazine, Espero Katolika (Catholic Hope), was founded in 1903.

Masses have been celebrated in Esperanto since 1981, mostly in Europe. In 1977, Vatican Radio began Esperanto broadcasts once weekly, increasing to twice a week in 1981 and three times a week in 1998.

In 1997, participants at the 50th IKUE congress were in St. Peter's Square when Pope John Paul II addressed them in Esperanto. The pope remains the only head of state to address the public in Esperanto regularly.

The World Almanac and Book of Facts estimates the number of Esperanto speakers at 2 million, compared with 487 million English speakers.

In the USA, Esperanto clubs are active in 26 states; there are five clubs in California alone. The Esperanto League for North America has 801 members. There are more than 20 newsgroups on the Internet for Esperanto speakers, and thousands of participants discuss everything from sex to science.

Ellen Eddy uses it "almost every day, especially in e-mail
correspondence," she says from her home in Olympia, Wash. "The language can be used for any purpose because it belongs to no one group."

That concept is what attracted her to Esperanto in 1969. "I liked the idea of a neutral language that would allow speakers to meet on an equal level."

Eddy is helping plan the 31st annual Esperanto Summer Seminar at San Francisco State University, June 26 to July 14.

Esperanto also has its detractors. "The reason it hasn't caught on is because it's always something the speaker has to learn in addition to his or her native, practical language - it's something extra," says Robert Trammell of the department of languages and linguistics at Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton.

"And as far as it being an 'international language' that doesn't
favor one speaker over another: No, it's essentially an Indo-European language with lots of Greek and Latin and Romance" influences.

Still, Eddy remains hopeful about Esperanto's future. "I think the rising cost of translating languages in the European Union and the United Nations has made the idea of a neutral second language for everyone more attractive today than ever."

New words in Esperanto are coined by the speakers themselves, but the core vocabulary of 1000+ roots were set a long time ago by its creator Dr. L. L. item.content:encoded:
Creating Livable Alternatives
 to Wage Slavery

Interesting site:  http://www.whywork.org/

<begin quote>

Welcome to CLAWS. We're a pro-leisure and anti-wage-slavery collective of people dedicated to answering the question "why work?"

We actively promote alternatives to the wage slavery mindset and what we call "The Cult of the Job" which equates a job with "making a living".

If you start asking yourself "why work?" you may discover the connection between wage slavery, misunderstandings of leisure, lifestyles based on consumption, corporate welfare, education that often amounts to little more than conditioning, and the global social and economic crises we are now facing. We hope that the materials we feature here will encourage critical thinking about such things.

<end quote>

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Lilipu: The Bonsai Language


http://purl.oclc.org/net/lilipu

Lilipu is a conlang or "constructed language." Like the miniature Japanese bonsai tree, Lilipu exemplifies "Small is beautiful." It is designed as a language in which to create haiku, a Japanese poetic style, usually about nature, which generally has three lines with 5 syllables on the first, 7 on the second, and 5 on the last.

In Papua New Guinea, there is a natural language called Rotokas spoken by about 4000 people. It has only 11 phonemes (sounds), consisting of 5 vowels and 6 consonants. This is the smallest known phonemic inventory in the world.

In Lilipu, my ambition was to beat Rotokas in being even smaller. I wanted only 9 phonemes: 3 vowels, 6 consonants. The whole Lilipu alphabet is: a, i, k, l, m, p, u, v, '. (The names of these letters in Lilipu are: 'a, 'i, ka, la, ma, pa, 'u, va, 'iki.)

The three vowels are:

a as in <father>
i as in <machine>
u as in <lunar>

The six consonants are:

k as in <skin>
l as in <love>
m as in <moo>
p as in <spin>
v as in <victory>

' is a glottal stop, which is like the catch in the throat between the two o's in "co-ordinate."

The stress in Lilipu is always the last syllable of a polysyllabic word like vuluLU or mimaVU. The syllable structure is always consonant+vowel. There are no consonant clusters or diphthongs.

--Viktoro


http://purl.oclc.org/net/lilipu

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
From the essay The Primitivist Critique of Civilization by Richard Heinberg:

"Having been chosen--whether as devil's advocate or sacrificial lamb, I am not sure--to lead off this discussion on the question, 'Was Civilization a Mistake?', I would like to offer some preliminary thoughts.

"From the viewpoint of any non-civilized person, this consideration would appear to be steeped in irony. Here we are, after all, some of the most civilized people on the planet, discussing in the most civilized way imaginable whether civilization itself might be an error. Most of our fellow civilians would likely find our discussion, in addition to being ironic, also disturbing and pointless: after all, what person who has grown up with cars, electricity, and television would relish the idea of living without a house, and of surviving only on wild foods?"

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have often thought about this question... It seems as though the more civilized we get, the more we lose sight of our basic humanity. I just hope in the rush to attain the highest possible civilized society, we don't end up destroying ourselves in the process.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The following is quoted from the website http://www.tokipona.org (author:  Christian Richard)

Toki Pona

Simple and Natural

Modern languages are cluttered with complex methods to express the simplest things.

What is a geologist but a person who studies the earth? Is there any useful difference between the words talk, speak, and say? Toki Pona breaks down all advanced ideas to their most basic elements. If you are hungry, you want eat. To teach is give knowledge.

This allows us to drastically reduce the vocabulary and grammatical structures needed to say what we have to say. Less is more.

Philosophy

A number of philosophies or principles have inspired me to create a language such as Toki Pona.

Toki Pona is semantically, lexically, and phonetically minimal. The simplest and fewest elements are used to create the maximum effect.

In many ways, Toki Pona resembles a pidgin. When people from different cultures need to communicate, they must focus on the concrete, simple things that are most universal to humanity.

Toki Pona follows the principles of Taoism, which advocates a simple, honest life and noninterference with the course of natural events.

I have also been inspired by anthropological primitivists such as Sahlins and John Zerzan, whose writings critique the totality of modern civilization, recognising the superiority of natural, primitive cultures.

Toki Pona can lead to an interesting game of semantic decomposition. Just as one can decompose a mathematical fraction such as 4/8 to 1/2, we can break down language to its most basic and tangible units of meaning and discover what things really mean.

According to reductionism, complex ideas and systems can be completely understood in terms of their simpler parts or components.

Since Toki Pona expresses things in their most natural and simple way, an inherent idea of goodness is transparent throughout the language. Health is good body. Happiness is feel good. Toki Pona itself means good language.

Above all, Toki Pona must be fun and cute. As everything seems to be oversimplified and ideas focus on the good, one could almost imagine a race of little cartoon creatures speaking in Toki Pona.

Cons

By being so general and vague, Toki Pona often lacks the ability to distinguish finer shades of meaning. For example, by lumping every possible bird species into one lexeme waso, we eliminate the need to learn hundreds of vocabulary items, however we are also left incapable of distinguishing between eagles and chickens. The closest translation might be an expression like waso wawa strong bird or waso nasa stupid bird.

Toki Pona has a rather narrow range of functions. Although it is very easy to communicate honest thoughts and everyday activities, it would be impossible to translate a chemical textbook or legal document in Toki Pona without significant losses. Such texts are products of the complex, artificial civilization we live in and are not suited for a cute, little language like Toki Pona.

Although the vocabulary and grammar are very simple, the language does contain a few basic syntax rules that are essential in keeping the sentence structure together. For instance, one must learn that the word li is used to separate the subject from the verb.

Etymology

The vocabulary was borrowed from other languages (see etymological dictionary) and adapted to the sounds of Toki Pona. The chief source languages are:

  • English
  • Tok Pisin
  • Finnish
  • Georgian
  • Dutch
  • Acadian French
  • Esperanto
  • Croatian
  • Chinese (Mandarin and Cantonese)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Paper Monitors

One of the futuristic ideas that most intrigued me from the movie "Minority Report" was the portrayal of really advanced display technology.  (I'm all hyped up for the future now.)  Monitors will be as thin and flexible as paper.  And they will be cheap!  Imagine holding a two-page "newspaper" while riding the subway.  With a touch of a button on the "paper,"  the next pages are displayed.  And animation of course will be possible.  Paper-thin screens!  It will be a revolution!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: nifty.
that sounds really cool

You and I both are too young to remember this, but I read where Henry Ford once said to his employees, "If I can think it up you can build it!" It's as good now as it was then!

ANd no waste of trees, either.

Minority Report

I saw "Minority Report" last night, a Steven Spielberg film, starring Tom Cruise.  I really enjoyed it.  It's set into the future, about 50 years from now.  Cops arrest people before they commit murder.  Psychics are used to find the "precrime."  It is very intriguing.  50 years from now, who knows what it'll be like, eh?  "The future is more interesting than the past."  I heard that in the movie.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The following geofictional article, which I wrote, can also be found at my website: http://www.geocities.com/vixcafe/ok.html

Urbo Ok

Situated on the southern coast of the North-Western Continent, along the Mesogaian Sea, is the romantic city called "Urbo Ok," which means "City 8" in Esperanto.  The city roughly fits in an area 1500 meters by 2500 meters.  It lies on an isthmus between the sea and a lake.

A light-rail route circles the city (see map). Other than the light-rail system and delivery trucks on the roads, all transportation on land is pedestrian or by bicycle.

The population of Urbo Ok is 110,230 at ZPG (zero population growth).  The population is multi-ethnic and multi-faith.

Urbo Ok is a 'conlang' (constructed language) community.  Esperanto is the main working language, but 10% of the population also speak Volapük as an art language.

The majority of Okans earn a living as artists, but a sizable minority do scientific research and development.

Public access to the Web is free for everyone.  There is a very large central library of all kinds of books.  Education until university postgraduate degree is free for all citizens.

The shopping malls are stocked with artwork and all necessities.  The culture dictates that buying someone else's admired artwork is good etiquette; it also helps the economy.

Urbo Ok is a model community in our world today.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Bilbo le hobbit

I'm reading The Hobbit by J. R. R. Tolkien in French.  I read the English version back in my adolescence.  This French version I like a lot.  The story has a different ambiance when read in a different language.  For those who don't know, The Hobbit is the precursor to the fantasy trilogy of The Lord of the Rings.  Yes, there are wizards, elves, magic, and those sorts of things in The Hobbit.

I've been reading French-language literature for the last two years and my reading skills have improved markedly.  I feel progress...  I can just feel the new neural pathways in my head by learning other languages.  I can read French a lot better and speak Esperanto a lot better too.  Learning other languages teaches one to think in more ways possible.  I devote more time to reading and the Internet by not watching TV!  I rarely do watch TV and when I do, I tend to watch TV5, the international French-language channel, where the programs are much better than the typical North American fare.  And I get to see European scenery, like medieval Salamanca in Spain and Bruges in Belgium.  Although, I don't understand all the French dialogue because the talking is too fast, but I'm getting adjusted.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Quick Esperanto Lesson

All nouns end in -o.  All adjectives end in -a.  Examples:

blua kato | blue cat

granda hundo | big dog

purpura planto | purple plant

rapida aeroplano | fast airplane

bruna domo | brown house

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks for the reminder.  I was trying to learn, but it's sort of confusing for me because of all my latin-based language background.  I just want to say bluo kato... make it agree, you know?

Hi Shawna!  About your comment about "blua kato" over which you want to say "bluo kato"--in Esperanto, there is no grammatical gender as in Spanish or Italian; the endings in Esperanto tell more about the part of speech the word plays rather than what gender it is...  Sometimes I think that grammatical gender as in Spanish is frivolous:  Why is "la mesa" (table) feminine?  What makes "el libro" (book) masculine?  It's totally arbitrary.  In Esperanto, this arbitrariness doesn't exist--no gender to memorize:  "la granda tablo" (the big table); "la nova libro" (the new book).  I hope this helps...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Kefi

Kefi.  That's one word I learned from my recent trip to Greece.  It's almost untranslatable, but roughly means a sense of intrinsic well-being and happiness.  In Canada, this "kefi" is hard to find.  Most Canadians are so reserved and grayish in temperament.  Maybe more "kefi" is found in sunnier climes.  Anyway, it's an agreeable philosophy.  I leave you with an interesting article by Jane Porter, more about "kefi"...

ONE NIGHT IN ATHENS

Offered by Jane Porter author of
THE ITALIAN GROOM AND CHRISTOS'S PROMISE

Okay, everybody, it's two o'clock in the afternoon. Nap time.

No, don't argue. You're going to need the sleep. We've got a long night ahead of us. After all, this is Athens, Greece and that mid-afternoon siesta (2-5 pm) is vital if we're going to be heading out tonight, and of course we're heading out. This is Athens and we won't be hitting bed much before 4 or 5 a.m.

Seriously.

Before you complain, know that many Athenians do this night after night-some even go out every night of the week--and everyone still makes it to work the next morning by 7:30 or 8:00.

How do Greeks do this? There's a word for it. Kefi. Kefi can best be described as a sense of well-being, combined with a pleasure in life. When Greeks get together, eat well, talk, listen to good music, they feel happiness - they feel comfort. That's kefi.

When a Greek is filled with this sense of deep satisfaction, he can't contain or ignore it. He is driven to express the happiness-he'll leave the table and dance. Think Zorba the Greek. Think emotion. Passion. Intensity. Not sexual-but spiritual, intellectual, and physical. A Greek feels with his whole heart and his whole body and has expressed himself with dance since the beginning of time.

Greek food embraces this passion. In many countries a great meal means an elegant restaurant, sophisticated cuisine, and immaculate service. But excellent meals in Greece can't be measured that way, as food-while exceptionally fresh and prepared with fine ingredients-isn't particularly sophisticated. No, a good meal in Greece is less about stiff tablecloths and white glove service than a connection to nature-views of the hills and sea-and the delicious bounty nature provides as in shrimp, swordfish brochettes, stuffed grape leaves, sliced artichokes kaskavalli and feta cheese, olives, tomatoes, peppers. Breads are fresh, hearty and simple. Salads are drizzled with olive oil and lemon juice. Hummus (ground chick peas with olive oil and garlic-yum yum!) is perfect for chunks of warm soft pita bread.
MORE...

naw--Canadians have uber-kefi...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Model Languages

http://www.langmaker.com/

Have you heard of model trains?  Model boats?  Well, there are now "model languages" - languages which are invented by hobbyists.  If you look at that LangMaker website, you'll see two of my entries, my two model languages called "Viko" and "Vong."  The LangMaker website is a repository of many people's model languages.  To that website, I also uploaded a "New English" word "mintellectual" (someone who dabbles on cerebral pursuits for refreshment, "mint" + "intellectual").  You can upload your own "New English" word to that website if you can think of one!

"At some point in the next century the number of invented languages will probably overtake the number of surviving natural languages."
     - Cullen Murphy in Atlantic Monthly (October, 1995)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
After my trip to Greece, I was inspired to write some fictitious travelogue through some imaginary country. "Geofiction" - the art of making imaginary countries - is a new hobby of mine. I found some other people doing it on the Web.

Travelogue on Sankta Lazaro 

My trip started off with a bad omen. The captain of the Air Canada airplane at the Vancouver International Airport was late fifteen minutes due to the "traffic" in town. Yes, the public announcement said it was due to "traffic" - on the road. I overheard one passenger whisper, "Where's that idiot?" The whole plane waited for this silly captain.

The flight itself was not too bad. It took eleven hours to reach Sankta Lazaro Airport. I had terrible gas on the plane, though. That was terrible. It must have been the potatoes for lunch. I saw The Matrix, an old science fiction movie, to pass the time. I could not really sleep. Perhaps I napped for less than an hour.

Sankta Lazaro Airport was small, but very modern. It was a breeze through customs. All the natives seemed friendly and always smiled. My luggage made it safely.

I stepped out of the airport and took a cab for my hotel. The cab was a top-model Mercedes Benz. Only North Americans would notice that.

As the taxi made its way through the town, I was in awe. All the buildings were white-washed. Some of the roofs would be in bold reds and blues, or pastel pinks and purples. Sankta Lazaro was a very pretty place. All the bright colours were for reflecting the bright sunlight, the taxi driver said.

I checked in at Hotelo Valentino. It was a beautiful hotel. There was a sunlit atrium with white marble floors. At the corners were large alabaster statues of the ancient gods of the island.

My room was spacious. It had a balcony overlooking water. I turned on the television as I was curious. All the channels broadcasted in Esperanto, the national language. It was a good thing that I learned some Esperanto before coming there. It seemed an easy language to grasp. I had a phrasebook. I learned that "Sankta Lazaro" was some saint. "Kie estas la necesejo?" meant "Where is the washroom?" "Saluton!" meant "Hello!" I could learn more as I go along. I was exhausted the first night and I slept like a log.

I arrived just in time for Easter celebrations. Most Lazarans are Mahayana Christians, but a sizable lot are Hare Krishnas and Buddhists. This time of the year, each Christian home would roast a whole lamb in the yard. The whole town would be filled with smoke from these roast pits. At night, there would be fireworks in the air. It was great picture-taking time.

The next day I toured the ancient ruins of Veluro. There I saw an ancient porcelain bathtub. Apparently, the ancient Lazarans were advanced. There were giant statues of men and women with the heads of animals like cats and elephants. The walls and columns were etched in a way that it looked like there were twisted vines on them. It was all organic-looking.

Sankta Lazaro has a long history. Recent history has seen waves of new immigrants come in such that it totally changed the demographics. Esperanto became the common language of this polyglot community by government decree in the 1930's.

The following days were relaxation. Sometimes I went to the beach. The water was still cold that time of the year, but it did not stop some of the Nordic tourists from wading in. Sometimes I walked through the old city, in the labyrinths of alleyways where donkeys were still used as transport. It was very picturesque.

The food was marvellous. Roasted lamb was the specialty of that time of year. But there were pasta dishes galore. The Lazarans also loved a lot of seaweed in their food. Lazarans were tea drinkers. They had a very sweet mint tea served in tiny cups. Breakfast was yoghurt and honey.

A few nights I wandered into clubs. The music was modern and funky; the lyrics were in Esperanto. I met a few girls. But my Esperanto was not advanced enough for deeper conversation. Besides, the music was too loud. I was not the clubbing type at home, so why should I bother elsewhere? Well, it was fun...

There was ample time for souvenir-shopping. I bought three small alabaster statues of animal-headed deities. For my friends, I bought postcards and cheap banners with Esperanto proverbs on them.

It was a marvellous trip, but I had to go home. I will always remember it in my heart. Sankta Lazaro was a magical land...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
25 Countries!

After my recent trip to Greece and Turkey, the number of countries in which I've lived or which I've visited is now 25!  I am so happy to have seen much of the world...  I've been to Asia, North America, Africa, and Europe.  There is so much variation in people and languages on this planet.  I'm quite satisfied with what I've seen and "touched" by all these places.

I try not to boast too much!

Here is a list of the countries I've been:

North America:  Canada, U.S.A., Mexico

Europe:  Vatican, Italy, Austria, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Germany, France, England, Spain, Portugal, Greece, Netherlands

Asia:  Japan, Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, South Korea, Hong Kong, Turkey

Africa:  Morocco, Egypt

One thing I've learned from travelling is "not to take life so seriously."

Of the countries that you have visited I have not visited Turkey,Egypt,Indonesia,South Korea, and Greece. I have also visited Poland, Denmark, Sweden and China.  There are a few more that escape me at this time!   Great to travel  !!!!!   @-}-}---

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The Olive Grove

I'm reading a fascinating book from the library called The Olive Grove:  Travels in Greece by an Australian-born Greek-Australian, Katherine Kizilos.  The book, part of the Lonely Planet Journeys series, is a wonderful travelogue on Greece.  Since I just got back from Greece, this reading is a great supplement.  It keeps the magic alive!

Here are a couple of quotes:

"Greece is full of people who are unashamedly idle.  Men and women will pull up a chair on the street outside their house and simply sit:  maybe something interesting will happen." (page 83)

"In Oia the sunset draws such crowds that twilight has become a theatrical event:  Tourism of the Absurd.  Every evening during the season, people race from the bus stop to the western edge of town, clutching their cameras.  They wander around Oia in the afternoon, asking where the sun goes down.  They vie for rooms with sunset views; on other islands I heard travellers talk about their desire to 'see the sunset' on Thira." (page 55)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
unashamedly idle

wonder what that feels like?
Do you know the story about the Greek fisherman and the American manager? Greek people are just shamelessly idle, that is what makes them so beautiful!
Would love to have the time to do that !  THoughts through the looking glass! @-}-}--

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Olympia

Can you believe it?  I've been back a week from my trip to Greece and I still have jet lag.  Today I fell asleep at 4 p.m. and woke up at 10 p.m.

The ruins of Olympia in Greece, which I visited, are really memorable.  While I was walking around there, I saw a girl walking by with the word "Esperanto" on her T-shirt.  I asked her, "Chu vi parolas Esperanton?" (Do you speak Esperanto?).  Then she answered, "Saluton!  Mi estas..."  From there we went on Esperanting.

She was from the Netherlands, camping around Greece.  She was heading to Sparta from Olympia, while I had just come from Sparta.  It's too bad I didn't take a picture of her.  It was a historical event for me because it was the first time I met an Esperantist outside of my home city in Canada.  It was true validation of the extent of the language, the "reality" of it...  Wow!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: so you've decided to donate or what? lol j/k thanks for the 2 eprops whoever you are

You sound like a very mature person, going up to a stranger like that. Who knows. Anyway, the jetlag must be normal. They say it takes one day for every hour in the time difference between where you are and where you were.
wow...that sounds like a trip of a life time. I'm planning to study abroad in europe in college.

I'm jealous!  I would love to go to greece.  This whole Esperanto....well, this information is entirely new to me, and according to your earlier post, I must live in a cave.  A cave of ignorance, I suppose.  My mother is tri-lingual and I just dabble, but I think I'll bring this up to her.  See what she has to say.  I'm really intrigued.......languages are fascinating to me.

Thanks for visiting!
I am so incredibly jealous of your going to greece - I would love to travel!  Especially to Italy or Sweden.  I hope you get over jet-lag soon - it's no fun!!

I hope you use the ability of taking naps...it is good that you are doing this. The jet lag is assisted if you take naps DURING your trip, too. You will survive and be the better for taking this marvelous trip. I so envy you for being in Greece. I will go one day!
Very very nice. Thanks.

I have done that trip a couple of times... no jetlag after the first time but then it only lasted 3 days... well, anyway, what a great experience you had!!!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Meteora

One of the most fascinating places that I visited in Greece is Meteora, where there are monasteries perched on top of mountain escarpments.  It's a great place to meditate and enjoy the view from a high altitude.

item.title: Volapük
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Volapük

This is an incredible story.  One night in Germany in March 1879, Father Johann Martin Schleyer (1831-1912) received a message from God, instructing him to have hope, and to create a new language that everyone in the world could speak.  A year later, he published Volapük or "world-speech."  It was the first "conlang" (constructed language) to encounter widespread interest and success. In its heyday, this invention claimed some 283 Volapük clubs, 316 textbooks, and 25-35 periodicals. But by the 1890's, the fad had waned due to politics and Volapük was soon eclipsed by a new conlang, Esperanto.  There had been a Volapük revival after Arie de Jong's revisions of the language in 1921-31.  In any case, Volapük is a work of art that is worth a look even though very few people speak it today. (The sign says "Menad bal pük bal" which means "One humanity, one language.")


Volapük Discussion List

Volapük Pronunciation

Volapük Vocabulary

Volapük Grammar

Volapop!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I heard about this language before but didn't know a German invented it! Do you speak that one as well? How come you know so much about languages? Please let me know!
Dear lonelydolphin:  No, I don't speak Volapük (yet?).  I know a lot about languages because I'm a hobby linguist...  Cheers!

I heard about Volupuk before myself. I knew that it wasn't as popular as Esperanto though... but the language itself looks very interesting and eloquent. I like the way the language is structured personally.

What are your favourite conlangs? I find the ones with the most exotic grammars to be particularly interesting to me as it allows me to think about things in an entirely different way.

Dear damienponech:

Toki Pona is one of my favourites (http://www.tokipona.org/).  The creator tries to embody Taoist concepts, a philosophy of simplicity, in his language...

I've invested a lot of leisure time learning Esperanto.  Sometimes I imagine it as a language vampires would use in a background of castles and mist.  I especially like the words that start with 'KV' like 'kvar'.  It's like a Romance language with a Germanic touch.  I like it.

But I want to learn Volapük too.  It seems like a charming language with an interesting history.  I'd rather learn that than Klingon.  I think Klingon is a little corny.

This is just a little note to everyone who might read this.  I will be away in Greece on vacation for a couple of weeks.  So you'll hear from me around mid-May.  Ciao! 

--Viktoro
Enjoyed my visit! Very interesting! @-}-}---
Interesting. I know about esperanto, not about this language.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Klingon and Esperanto

If you have not heard of either Klingon or Esperanto, you probably live in a cave.  Well, Klingon is well known among Star Trek fans, Trekkies, as the language of a space-faring warrior race called the Klingons.  Esperanto is noteworthy as a serious candidate for an (some say "the") International Language of our own planet Earth.  While Klingon is frivolous and fantastical, Esperanto is serious and idealistic.

Klingon and Esperanto are what are known as "conlangs" (constructed languages).  Sometimes these are also known as "artificial languages."  Now it gets deeper.  While Esperanto is an "auxlang" (auxiliary language promoting international communication), Klingon is an "artlang" (an artistic language created as an aesthetic expression).

Behind the background of the glamorous television subculture, Klingon was created by Marc Okrand when his book The Klingon Dictionary came out in the 1985.  Esperanto was created around the time of the building of the Eiffel Tower, in 1887, by a Polish oculist Dr. L.L. Zamenhof (or Doctor Esperanto).  That is almost a century apart.  Klingon has the support of a vibrant science fiction subculture, while Esperanto today attracts many leftists, religious types, and utopists from around the world.

While Esperanto is meant to be super easy to learn, Klingon is meant to be very difficult to learn.  Esperantists know about the Sixteen Rules all too well.

While Esperanto has the serious goal of eliminating the world's communication problems, Klingon has the goal of entertaining.

While Klingon is backed by a capitalist marketing machine, Esperanto is left to volunteers for grassroots support.

They fulfill different wants and needs.

Now, we can take a look and compare the two languages structurally...

The Klingon alphabet has 26 letters, a mixture of lowercase and uppercase:

a b ch D e gh H I j l m n ng o p q Q r S t tlh u v w y '

This alphabet of Roman letters is only a handy representational tool for non-Klingons; written Klingon uses its own exotic glyphs called the pIqaD.  Klingon has some notoriously difficult sounds (for English-speakers):  coarse and raspy (gh, H), and  guttural (q, Q).  The sound of 'tlh' may be found in the Earth language of Aztec (Nahuatl) too.  It is the simultaneous enunciation of T and L.  The apostrophe (') marks a glottal stop, like catch in the throat between the two o's of "coordinate."  Klingon has the air of a barbarian, vulgar language.

The Esperanto alphabet has 28 letters:

a b c cx d e f g gx h hx i j jx k l m n o p r s sx t u ux v z

The only difficult sound for English-speakers is 'hx', which is like the 'ch' in German "Bach" or Scottish "loch."  This is the same as the Klingon letter 'H'.  The letter 'c' is like 'ts' in "its"; 'cx' is like 'ch' in "church"; 'gx' is like 'g' in "George"; 'jx' is like 'z' in "azure"; 'sx' is like 'sh' in "ship"; 'ux' is like 'w' in water; and 'j' is like 'y' in "yoyo."

Klingon is an OVS (Object-Verb-Subject) language.  English is SVO if you did not know.  The Klingon " jIb Sop ghargh" means "a worm eats hair"; jIb is "hair," Sop is "eat," and ghargh is "worm."  The order is reversed from English.  Now, Esperanto is customarily like English (SVO), so that "vermo mangxas haron" means the same; vermo is "worm," mangxas is "eats," and haro is "hair."  Adding an '-n' to "haro," we get "haron" which is the form for the direct object.  This 'n' signals the direct object.  This allows Esperanto to be SVO, SOV, VSO, VOS, OSV, or OVS.  So sentences like "haron mangxas vermo," "mangxas haron vermo," and "vermo haron mangxas" all mean "a worm eats hair" and are all grammatically correct.  It is flexible.

Klingon has no adjectives.  It has verbs to cover for them.  For example, "tun" means "to be soft" so that "ghargh tun" means "worm [which] is soft" (soft worm).  In Esperanto, the suffix '-a' marks the adjective, so that "mola vermo" is "soft worm."  The suffix '-o' marks the noun.

Both Klingon and Esperanto are agglutinative languages.  Prefixes, suffixes, and roots combine to form bigger, more complex words.  A Klingon example is "yuQmeymajDaq" (on our planets):  "yuQ" is "planet"; "-mey" is a pluralizer; "-maj" is "our" and "-Daq" signals location.  An Esperanto example is "malsanulejo" (hospital); "mal-" signals opposite; "san-" means "health"; "-ul" means a person; "-ej" means a place; and "-o" signals a noun.  All in all, it is "a place for unhealthy ones."  It makes sense.

Klingon verbs have no tense.  Esperanto does:  '-as' (present), '-is' (past), '-os' (future).  "Mi vidas" (I see).  "Mi vidis" (I saw).  "Mi vidos" (I will see).  Klingon expresses these ideas from context or extra signals like "wa'Hu'" (yesterday).  Klingon does indicate aspect:  whether an action is completed or not yet, or is continuing or a single instance.   An example is '-taH' for continuous aspect:  "SoptaH" (it is eating).  Among Earth languages, Chinese is a lot like Klingon about its verbs; Chinese has no tense, but it has aspect.

As you might see, the vocabulary of Klingon is entirely alien, not being based on an Earth language, of course, because the Klingon homeworld is supposedly somewhere in deep space.  Esperanto is a synthesis of cognate terms from European languages, so knowing Spanish, French, German, Italian, or English already will help in accumulating a learner's vocabulary:  "La birdo flugas al la alta arbo kaj kantas melodion" (The bird flies to the tall tree and sings a melody).  You can find the similarities.

A startling difference between the two languages can be gauged in the bookstore.  Esperanto books can be found in the language section among Chinese Made Easy, Beginner's French, Swedish-English Dictionary, and other such books, while Klingon books can be found in the science fiction section among the Star Trek literature.  The public perception about and the marketing of the two languages are entirely different.

This article has delved into some of the differences between Esperanto and Klingon.  Both are products of very fertile imaginations.  Creative people would perhaps admire them.  Klingon is for amusement.  Esperanto can also amuse, but it has a more serious goal in mind as a universal language.  Are they permanent fixtures in our universe?  Well, Esperanto has had enthusiastic speakers for more than a century, so clearly it has lasting power.  Because Klingon is a more recent phenomenon, we do not know how long it will remain in the public mind.  It may depend on the continuing popularity of the Star Trek saga and the continuing presence of charming Klingons therein.  But who knows?  It is art after all.

I leave you with a poem (haiku) in three languages:  Klingon, Esperanto, and English respectively:

jaghpu' yuQmeyDaq
no'Homchaj tuHqu' Sopbej
gharghHommeyna' tun.

Cxe malamikoj--
Vermetoj certe mangxas
Hontajn praulojn.

On our foes' homeworlds--
Soft little worms surely eat
Their ashamed forebears.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Kwa:dakw

The Kwa:dakw are a tribe of native people who live on the heavily forested Queen Marie Islands off the coast of the Adanak mainland. They are known for their exquisite art and handicrafts, as well as marvellous village architecture and totem poles. To this day and age, much of their way of life is well-preserved.

The word "kwa:dakw" itself means "wild" or "untamed," alluding to the spirit of the Kwa:dakw people.

See more of this fiction at my website:  http://ca.geocities.com/vixcafe/kwaadakw

Craigdarroch Castle, Victoria, B.C., Canada

I visited this castle last week.  It is truly beautiful.  I could almost imagine myself living in that majestic place in a simpler era.  I was really impressed.  The Scots Gaelic name is pronounced "Kreygderik" according to a lady that works there.

I quote from a website:

"Located a short drive or a leisurely walk from the downtown harbour, just off Fort Street at 1050 Joan Crescent, Victoria, BC, Canada, Craigdarroch Castle is a beautiful historic Victorian-era mansion, built in the 1890s by wealthy BC coal baron Robert Dunsmuir. It is now owned by the Craigdarroch Castle Historical Museum Society and almost totally funded by its 150,000 annual visitors.

"Craigdarroch Castle was built as the home of Robert Dunsmuir, the richest man in nineteenth century British Columbia."

Looks like a fun place to camp out at.

I wish I could spend months in such a place, to walk the halls by day, absorb the essence of the walls, and imagine who walked before me. Then write the stories at night, wanting only to wake for another day of the same.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Cold North

I'm glad spring is coming.  There's nothing worse than cold and rainy in the winter.  Personally, I like hot and rainy in the tropics better than cold and rainy in the North.  Well, I like hot better than cold.  So why do I live in the cold North?  I ask that to myself sometimes.  I think it is to do with family.

"...a happiness independent of conditions..."

I am quoting someone. That's what I want.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: What North ? It is always the north of something ! ! !
Michel:  C'est le Nord...  le Nord froid...
Amen, brother....that's what I want, too. Seems some people are determined to undermine whatever it is we want, our inner peace. Wonder how they would feel if the shoe was on the other foot?
I don't like cold wet winters, either. The older I get, the more I like summer. I hope to retire someplace where they've never heard of winter.
I don't ever again want to live where palm trees don't grow. August in Houston is never as bad as February in Pittsburgh.
I grew up and spent most of my life in Georgia, so Indiana is now a change of pace for me.  But my next residence might be in Florida.     Or Salem, Mass.....who knows....?
If you like tropical weather and you're a nature lover, try visiting the Philippines. Regards.
Oh...I long for spring and summer. I don't like the heat...,but I like the colours and the green trees and...and...and....

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Krishnamurti and Pathlessness

My friend mentioned to me that he was reading a book by Jiddu Krishnamurti, a renowned philosopher of the 20th century.  I was curious, so I searched the Web.

Krishnamurti said:  "I maintain that truth is a pathless land, and you cannot approach it by any path whatsoever, by any religion, by any sect."

As a beginning Buddhist who has learned the "Eightfold Path," I find this "pathless" path intriguing. If life is a journey, do we not follow a "path"? Are there any Krishnamurtists out there? I'm getting curious about that "pathless" point of view. It seems anarchic...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Jesu shows us the path but I know you left .

Amitié à toi .

Michel

Autrefois tu mettais un petit texte en Français . c ' était sympathique .

It isn't.

The truth is in you...

it's peace.

Whenever you are not thruthfull,

you feel quilty,

or uneasy,

irritated,

whatsoever.

When you tell the truth...

you stay close to yourself...

no need to walk a path...

just be what is.....

I think pathless is a way of phrasing non-defined journey or something.. like adventuresque.. hmm.. I don't know really..

-NΛVĐΞΞP

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
I'm back!

I was in the Philippines for several weeks.  I had a great time.  The weather was great!  The food was fantastic!  There were bountiful coconut trees, banana trees, and papaya trees.

I have five rolls of film that I have to get developed.  One of these days I will create an animated Flash presentation composed of some of the pictures and put it on the web.  If I can get a photo CD when I get the film developed, it would be great so I don't have to scan pictures.  I'll keep you posted about that.

Life seems good over there in the Philippines despite the poverty.  People are really friendly.  People are always smiling.  Fruits and delicious goodies are in abundance.  Labor is cheap so all middle-class and upper-class people, living like royalty, have maids and drivers.

It is a beautiful country!

Far Away
