item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded: As for the design of a national flag, I like Papua New Guinea's (above).  I think red and black are a striking combination.  Although that yellow bird figure would be difficult for young kids to draw at school.  I also like Brazil's flag (below) in the green, yellow, and blue.  It looks very natural and friendly.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Les deux se complètent en apportant les 3 couleurs fondamentales : bleu , vert , rouge.

Both flags are completing each other in offering the 3 basic colours : blue , green , red .

Have you noticed?, both have the Southern Cross stars. I also like the Brazilian flag, except for one thing in the white stripe. The phrase "Ordem e Progresso" (Order and Progress), an heritage of Comte´s positivism.

When I was a kid at school we had to draw the flag and it was difficult to put the right number of stars (26, same # as states, plus one above, the federal district) in the right position. But drawing the sky is always nice. By the way, the color symbols are: green for the forests, yellow for the wealth [gold], blue for the sky, and white for peace.

Dauro, from Brasil
i've also always loved the color and design of brazil's flag. bahrain's is beautiful, too: left third white, two-thirds red, with zig-zag line between them like they were cut with pinking shears.

I am a flag lover!!! I like the Nepal flag for it's shape, Tibet for it's colors and meaning... The Star Spangled Banner for it's meaning and uniqueness... on and on... If you want to talk about flags, you are always welcome, just tell me and we can chat... flags is a real addiction for me...
Btw... forgot the Maple Leaf...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Sun or Son?

I have a collection of flags at home.  One of them is the Japanese flag.  One day my niece, Tria, who is three and half years old, was playing and looking at it.  She asked, "What's that?" referring to the red disk.  I said, "the sun."  She said, "You mean God?"  As you see, my niece goes to a pre-nursery school at a Roman Catholic church although neither of her parents are religious or Roman Catholic; the school is just conveniently close to home.  I'm thinking that maybe Tria is confused with the "sun" and the "Son" (Christian God).  Maybe she is thinking that the sun is God, like the Sun God, Ra, of ancient Egypt.  Tria, the sun-worshipper...  he! he!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That's pretty cute.

Je pense que ta nièce a fait une remarque pertinente . Evidemment sans parle de Dieu - soleil on peut dire que le soleil source d ' énergie et de vie peut être une belle image pour évoquer Dieu , une image seulement . Intelligente , ta nièce .

I think that your niece has made a pertinent remark . Obviously it is not here a Sun- God but the sun source of energy and life can be a nice and temporary picture of God , only a picture .Beside we cannot figure God . She is intelligent your niece .

Amitié à toi

Michel

nice story.
Sorry I haven't been around in a while, but I'm kinda busy working on my fiction... my Creative Writing teacher says it lacks strength of unity.
Got to go.

that is soooo cute! i the faith of children. i wish i had such faith still. *sigh*

~ remikins
peace to you my friend
Cute girl! I love the imaginations of children!

Your niece is cute.

BTW, I am a Japanese, but I don't like the design of the Japanese flag, "Hinomaru." It's too simple.

The year before last, the flag was legally recognized in Japan.
Sorry. I made a mistake. Two years ago, the law about the flag was established, and the flag is now legally recognized.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Bamiyan Statues

On March 2001, the Taliban exploded the two giant Buddha statues of Bamiyan in Afghanistan.  These were sculpted around the 3rd century A.D.  It's just terrible!  Such was the Taliban's religious intolerance.

True Buddhists may only repeat one of their beliefs for the conditions of existence:  "everything is impermanent."  That may be, but I did hear on the radio that there are efforts to restore the statues and create replicas once Afghanistan is stabilized.  I wonder if that will succeed.  It would be a huge undertaking.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I hope this undertaking will succeed .
Yeah, it's so sad.  The people of the Taliban really should take time while they are taken captive, to study the world's cultures and realize how horrible all the crap they've been doing is.

I agree that it was a terrible act, and indicative of what the Taliban were all about - however the question of Afghanistan becoming stable is by far the biggest question at the moment, one that requires a lot of give and take on all sides, but that that requires people to almost forgive the unforgivable.
I´ve read in the news about plans of rebuilding the Buda statues here in Brasil, in the central highlands.
Oh man, that is really sad that such pieces of history and culture were destroyed under the command of a few crazy extremists.

That is right, everything is impermanent, but as a Buddhist I have to say that it still hurts that this had happend. No one can bring the statues back as they were so I'd rather let them damaged! Maybe as a reminder of how many innocent lives the Taliban took.
They've asked the Japanese government for help in funding the rebuilding, but with Japan's economy in a recession, I don't see it happening any time soon.

Indeed that was a terrible thing that happened.  I truly do hope they succeed in doing it,  but it will be a very lengthy and costly process.    Good luck and May God Bless you & all your endeavors, in the New Year!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Off the Beaten Path

Staying away from chickens
running around without heads,
I notice only a barn
full of guinea pigs
living peaceful lives in hay.
Sayonara to the rain and mud.
Only the wind reminds me
that I am on earth.
Flocks of tropical birds sing
a rock and roll symphony.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Slower Time, Better Life

I attended an Esperanto lunch and meeting on Saturday at a Chinese restaurant.  An Esperantist, who was not one of our regular attendants and whose name was Win, said to all at the table, "Tiu, kiu malrapidigas la tempon bonigas la vivon."  That translates to "That which slows down time enriches life."  I thought how apt that line was to my life.  I like taking my time.  I have friends who seem to be always in a hurry and I just don't see the point in all the rush.  I actually practice slowing down:  I would sit at a restaurant drinking my hot tea for many minutes after I eat, making sure I feel "settled."  Maybe if I lived in Paris or Vienna, I could sip my coffee for hours at a café just watching the world go by.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
me too. i need to be in europe. around here if you try to sit and drink coffee or tea after words they look at you like "when is he going to leave so we can make more $$$"

or give you your check while your still finishing eating and haven't even asked you for tea or coffee yet. or dessert.

or what if you just want coffee ir tea and nothing else? i think you need a permit for that.

When I had a job and went to school my life was rush rush rush and I was EXTREMELY unhappy so I wisened up and quit.  Now it's school Monday through Friday and do nothing of any particular importance on the weekends and having two "slow days" has proven to be good for your sanity.

PS  I'd like to go to Europe too 'cause it seems cool and what more could a child ask for than to have an ocean, some time zones, including the prime meridian and a few country boarders between her and her parents?

As soon as I get to my house I will sit down and have a cup of tea and really enjoy it. I have always drank it for it caffine or because it's abreak from the norm.

Thanks
Settling down is extremely hard in Europe! I agree with stuftmj, they only want to make money here, no time to rest! I wish I could go to where you live once! {{{Hugs}}}

they say if you sit in a cafe long enough you will see everyone in the world pass by.  *sigh* what a romantic though!!

~thinkpink~
I Like it. We say :The time you spend at table does not make you old.true,but makes you heavy.

A french proverb says : " hâte - toi lentement "

translate : " more haste , less speed "

He who is there above, await him below. (Pride will have a fall.)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Ancient Classic

I'm reading the only available translation to a Western language of the Taoist classic Wen-tzu, written more than 2000 years ago; the book title is Further Teachings of Lao-tzu by Thomas Cleary.

From Chapter 53:  "The Way is to preserve what you already have, not to seek what you haven't got.  If you seek what you haven't got, then what you have is lost; if you go along with what you have, then what you want will come."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: great advice for those who would take heed

It ' s a kind of wisdom but which asks to be well understood .

Jesus says the same in Beatitudes .

"Use what you have got and then you won't need what you have not."

~ from the cartoon version of Around the World in 80 Days
Great quote, but Buddha is saying about the same, only that achievement in wealth is nothing, only what you gathered in your mind counts!
damn. where'd you find that? i've been looking everywhere for it.
To stuftmj:  It was in my local library...  After I read it, I felt so calm.
thanks. i'm going to scour mine today.
That is the ideal way to live. I hope one day to find that sort of tranquility of mind and soul.
yeah.

The storm passed over
the island of the blue mangos,
like a furious Big Brother.
The wind whipped the jungle;
flora and fauna had no place to hide.
The massive downpour drenched the streets.
It was not a time for festivities.
La tempête se passait.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Zardoz

[Picture disappeared]

A stone head floats in the sky...  Zardoz, a classic science fiction movie is one of my favorites, and at times is my favorite.  Rent it out if you have not yet seen it.  It stars Sean Connery and Charlotte Rampling.  It is about the future when people live in a utopia, play god, and never die.  People live so long that they yearn for the end.  The movie is full of satire and intrigue, smooth and elegant.  Zed (Connery) is the hero who brings back mortality and the "natural" order.  The name "Zardoz" is from the "Wizard of Oz."
